bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, September 5, 1950

div1.p: Hench writes to Truby that he was distressed to learn about the death of Kean. He praises Kean and his work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, September 5, 1950
div1.opener:
September 5, 1950
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I am sure that you were as greatly distressed as I to hear of
the sudden death of General Kean. I am greatly disturbed. He was such
a wonderful man. Colonel Siler wrote me last week that General Kean had
entered Walter Reed because of urinary retention and an enlarged prostate and
that prostatectomy was being considered. When I heard this on Friday, I
dictated a note to Colonel Siler in my anxiety, hoping that by some ethical
means one could make the urgent request in favor of a punch operation rather
than a prostatectomy. The former is much simpler and safer in any event,
certainly in a man of 90. Before mailing the letter I consulted one of our
urologists who agreed with me but we decided properly that there was nothing
I could do by giving long-distance advice, except perhaps make trouble.
Therefore, I refrained from doing anything.

Yesterday I had a letter from General Kean's son saying that
his father had gone to Walter Reed two weeks ago and that it was evident
that prostatectomy would be in order; however because of a sharp drop in
blood pressure an abdominal cystoctomy was done under local anesthesia.
He did fairly well until August 30 when he had a slight stroke. The next
day he could answer questions but there was some paralysis of the left arm.
He was resting fairly comfortably. This morning came a wire from Colonel
Siler that he died about 6 o'clock last night.

I feel almost as if I had lost a father. I wish indeed I could
go to the funeral but I am head over heels in work trying to get ready to
go to Europe in three weeks. Furthermore, My associate, Doctor Polley,
will be leaving tomorrow for a month in California, speaking in San Francisco
by the way, and Los Angeles.

General Kean was a grand man and it has been one of the great
privileges of my life to have known him and a few of his comrades, including
yourself.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
